results.description:
CSS Preprocessors are all the rage these days and they should be. Designing and developing web based user experiences is growing both more challenge and more exciting. CSS, our trusty friend, is inflexible, static, and unwieldy for today's needs. CSS Preprocessors fill the void and open up a whole new arsenal of tools for designers and developers.

So whether you are an advanced user, beginner, or sceptic, come to the first meetup for NYC Sass/Compass user group. We are planning on keeping this a monthly meeting and will have the next two at New Work City.

We have an open format planned for the first meeting. We want to cover what you want, so let us know. We'll review the suggestions and post the format at the end of next week. And while ideally this kickoff should have you convinced why we pick Sass over LESS, we will be happy to have a lightening talk on the subject.

Future meetings will eventual evolve to more structured presentation format. If you are using Sass & Compass and want to talk about your work and approach, please reach out to CS.

If there's a better day/date to consider for next month's meetup, let us know.

Speaker list:

Scott Kellum wrote Sass Modular Scale, contributes to Sassy Math, and is currently working on Singularity. Scott works at Roger Black Studio on Treesaver. Mason Wendell is a Coding Designer. He's the creator behind Survival Kit, a contributor to TheSassWay and runs the Philadelphia Sass Meetup. Mason is Creative Director at Zivtech. Sam Richard is the creator of Aura, A Sass+Compass based Responsive Website framework built with Modular Scale and Susy. He's a contributor to Sassy Math. Sam works at WorkHabit Claudina Sarahe is an independent consultant currently working with web based startups on product design and development. She speaks on Sass and Compass and uses it for all her work. She recently completed the new Studio Daniel Libeskind.
results.name: Syntactic Awesomeness! Debut of NYC Sass & Compass Monthly Meetup
Rapid Site Development with Sass & Compass

results.description:
"Responsive Web Design is hard. Really hard, actually." The opening words to Jeff Croft's insightful post about his development approach with Sass. Yes, responsive is challenging. It is changing the way we think about design; the way we architect our CSS, as we move to from thinking in 960px to thinking about mobile first and designs that will look good at any size; it is changing our perception, workflow, attitude, and swagger. Not since the birth of Web Standards has the web development community received such a resounding shake up. The explosion of CSS Preprocessors couldn't have come at more needed time. We need all the help we can get!

In the words of John Albin, Front-End Developer extraordinaire and creator of Zed Grids, the only way to do responsive web is with a css preprocessor. Sass, especially with its newest release 3.2, outshines the other two CSS Preprocessors when it comes to @media handling. First Sass lets us remove all the junk and rigidity of grid classes from our markup; Second, Sass does all the heavy lifting with is solid math functions–write your own or use one of the many grid extensions available–to spit out those % values down to the 100th value; Third media bubbling keeps stylesheets logical and legible; Fourth, the @content directive and addition of variables in Sass 3.2 blow it all out of the water allowing us to create power mixins that "respond to" different devices; Fifth, Sass along with new tools, like beloved Live Reload, bring Photoshop to the browser, getting you in the medium faster.

For the rest and much more on principles and philosophies of Responsive Web join us Tuesday, June 19th 7PM at New Work City for presentations by Mason Wendell, VP of Creative at Zivtech, and Sam Richard, Front-end Developer at World Economic Forum. This third installment of NYC Sass is not to be missed. Not to worry though, this revolution will be televised.

The Speakers

Mason Wendell has been writing, coding, and touting the magic of Sass and Responsive since before we even decided to open our ears to the magic flute of CSS Preprocessor. He's the creator behind Survival Kit, coined the term Coding Designer, and author of many articles on RWD in Sass. His work has inspired many, including Jeff Croft who sites Mason's articles as the inspiration for his respond-to gist.

Sam Richard is one of the leading voices on Sass and Responsive as well as frequent collaborator and friend of Mason. He has given talks on RWD at Meetups and Conferences the world over. His recent article, Principles of Responsive Web Design is one of the most thorough and expansives look on RWD since Marcotte's seminal text. A must read!

The Talk

Mason and Sam will be giving a combined session for the length of the meetup covering the whole Sass+RWD stack with an intermission for a lightning talk on Susy, the responsive grid framework for Compass, so strap in and prepare to have your socks blown off.

Live Streaming

We will be live streaming this event on the Sass Meetups Ustream.tv channel

Good Reads by Mason Wendell

Responsive Web Design in Sass: Using Media Queries in Sass 3.2

Responsive Web Design in Sass Part 2: Media Queries in Sass

Responsive Web Design in Sass Part 1: Fluid Layouts and Fluid Images
results.name: Responsive Web Design with Sass (aka The Right and Only Way to do Responsive)

results.description:
Huzzah! This month we take a look at the cool, shiny things you can do with Sass that would be maddeningly difficult, if not impossible, to do with CSS. We'll hear from three incredibly talented developer-designers–John Refano, Scott Kellum, and Albert Tholen.

John Refano (@threehz) will be giving a guided tour of some of the things he has built for Behance, showing how Sass can make your life a lot easier and help out with the creation some cool visual effects. You may even learn more about plain old CSS3 in the process.

Scott Kellum (@scottkellum) made Sassy Modular Scale, a Sass project inspired by and adapted from Tim Brown's modularscale.com. Check out the great article about this project on The Sass Way (http://thesassway.com/projects/modular-scale) and then come learn from Scott how he built and uses Sassy Modular Scale to bring harmony to his designs and projects.

Albert Tholen (@albert_tholen) wrote a Sass script extension to bring the math behind Photoshop's powerful soft-light gradient blending mode to Sass, which eliminates the need for making soft-light gradient backgrounds manually and allows a designer to create beautiful CSS3 gradients in-browser.

Our lightening talk dives into Control Directives, a pretty killer Sass feature that sets it apart from the other CSS Preprocessors. Good prep read: http://thesassway.com/intermediate/if-for-each-while

Speakers

John Refano (johnrefano.com | @threehz) is a web developer with a degree in design, residing in Brooklyn, NY. He is member of the dev team at Behance, and an long time Sass enthusiast. He loves CSS3 and making things as beautiful as they are functional.

Scott Kellum (scottkellum.com | @scottkellum) is a designer of all trades: graphic, web, typeface, print, publication. He currently works for Vox Media. Scott is behind many Sass extensions from Sassy Math to Singularity, a responsive grid system designed to be as flexible and small as possible while still providing an enormous amount of power. Scott also resides in Brooklyn, NY.

Albert Tholen (@albert_tholen) is a web development intern for Lua Technologies, Inc. He studies film and computer science at Wesleyan University. There, he works on web design and development when his schoolwork sees fit to grant him some free time.

Thank you to our Sponsors!

VOX Media sponsors all the great refreshments. VOX is hiring and you'll get to use Sass in Ruby on Rails environment.

New Work City has been providing space for NYC Sass from Day 1. Independents, entrepreneurs, and freelancers looking for great community should checkout co-working at NWC.
results.name: Sa$$Y Bling

results.description:
Our inaugural play/hack day for the NYC Sass community to come together and hack on projects, be them beginner, intermediate, or advanced projects. Bring projects, questions, or come to help out if you are a more advanced user.

Big thanks to our member, Matt, for organizing the space.
results.name: Sass+Compass Playday
Back to Basics: Sass and Compass

results.description:
The world is getting hip to Sass! Posts and primers about Sass are more and more ubiquitous. But unless explicitly declared, you'll never know if a site has been built with Sass. That's where NYC Sass comes in. We are here to answer the burning question: "How'd they do that?"

Cemre Güngör, Designer/Founder of much anticipated startup Branch, and Ward Penny, developer at buzzy Chole and Isabel, are taking the stage to talk about how they are leveraging sass.

Cemre is going to talk about how they make our life easier at Branch using SASS: How Branch built their pattern and mixin library, including their grid mixins which helped them make the site responsive faster, how Branch uses icon fonts, some pitfalls to avoid with overusing @extend's, and lots more.

Ward is going to talk about making beautiful (and Responsive) product with Sass + Compass on Shopify.

This month is also super special–it's our 6-month anniversary!! If you've been to our events, you know how we roll. Expect some anniversary extravaganza. We're thrilled to have made it to this point. We wouldn't be here if it weren't for the fabulous support from you, our members and the amazing developers/designers that have stepped up to present. The 17th is for you. Come learn, eat, drink, and rock your sassiness.

Sponsors

A super big thanks to Pivotal Labs for sponsoring the space for our Meetup. Sustaining sponsor Vox Media provides us with all the beer, fruit, chips, and snacks.

Speakers


Cemre (@gem_ray) Designer Founder of Branch, formerly at Etsy and NYU.

http://cem.re

Ward Penney (@wardpenney) is a UX designer and front-end developer and coming up on his 1-year NYC anniversary. Currently Senior UX Designer @chloeandisabel.

wardpenney.com
results.name: Sass in the Wild: At Branch & Responsive E-commerce with Shopify

results.description:
This month, we're collaborating with the New York Agile Experience Design Meetup ! to talk about the strength of Sass as technical tool for implementing agile and experience design driven methodologies, as well as a tool that allows designers and developers to craft new practices that put usability and design at the helm.

This meetup we'll have a number of sessions (10-15 min each), followed by general panel-type discussion. We have three members from NYC Sass group and we'll be adding a couple from Agile Experience Design group shortly–stay tuned!

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/d/3/e/2/event_168054242.jpegJonathan Berger is a designer, developer and technologist. He spends his days building software with Pivotal Labs and his nights and weekends working on Market Publique. Jonathan is going to talk about Spike Driven Design.

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/d/4/5/0/event_168054352.jpegJean-Pierre is Founder of Zybragroup, a design and development agency and he'll present on Agile Wordpress Theme Design with Sass. He'll cover how he uses helper partials to aid building responsive themes.


http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/d/4/8/2/event_168054402.jpegMark Reilly is a User Experience Designer for NYU's Information Technology Services. He is a hybrid web designer, front end developer and is a Sass and Compass enthusiast. He's going to present on Sassy Style Tiles, an open source solution to quickly and easily generating style tiles in CSS and HTML using Sass and Compass. Style Tiles (http://styletil.es) is a great solution for getting away from Photoshop comps. They allow a separation of style from layout. Especially now with responsive web design there's no longer a definitive layout. However, style tiles are still being generated in Photoshop or FireWorks! Sassy Style Tiles lets you design in the browser not in pixel based AdobeLand.

http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/d/4/b/4/event_168054452.jpegMason Wendell is VP of Creative at Zivtech and is going to talk about using Sass for prototyping and designing/developing with a styleguide driven approach. Mason is the creator behind Survival Kit, Breakpoint, coined the term Coding Designer, and author of many articles on RWD in Sass.

Agenda

6:30 to 7:00pm - Space opens, meet & greet.

7:00 to 8:30pm - Presentation, discussion.

Unlike our other meetups, we do have a space cap. If you have a spot and change your mind, please do try to take your name off the list. We hope you can join us!

Big thank you to our sponsors Vox Media for food and Pivotal Lab for the space, drinks, and snacks
results.name: Agile Experience Design and Sass: A Co-Meetup

results.description:
Yeah responsive is all the rage... but how do you design build and deploy a responsive site for an enterprise brand? NYC Sass Meetup welcomes Matt Schiffman and Scott Kellum to talk about the process of designing and developing enterprise responsive sites with sass.

Matt Schiffman will take you through the process from IA/UX, through coding. You'll get to see sass in all its pro action glory, along with a little bit of flash, jade and some fun JavaScript frameworks.

Scott Kellum (Coming Soon!)

We will be taking cash donations for Hurricane Sandy

Speakers

http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/8/1/b/c/event_178473212.jpegMatt specializes user interface design and front-end development. He was born, raised and started a family in NYC. He operates his consulting business Darrow Digital Media out of the Brooklyn Creative League in Gowanus Brooklyn. He labels himself a maker of digital things and executes more than he ideates… most of the time.

Scott Kellum (scottkellum.com | @scottkellum) is a designer of all trades: graphic, web, typeface, print, publication. He currently works for Vox Media. Scott is behind many Sass extensions from Sassy Math to Singularity, a responsive grid system designed to be as flexible and small as possible while still providing an enormous amount of power. Scott also resides in Brooklyn, NY.

Sponsors

Pivotal Labs creates great software. They support NYC Sass by allowing us to host our monthly meetups from their offices. Thank you @pivotallabs for the space and great refreshments.

Vox Media is a sustaining NYC Sass sponsor. Vox sponsors food and helps NYC bring in out of state speakers. Thank you @voxmediainc for your support since day 1.
results.name: Real World Responsive Design & Development for Enterprise: Process, IA, & Sass

results.description:
Underneath it all Sass is still CSS. We gotta love the language that brings beauty to the web. Let's bid a celebratory adieu to 2012 with one more NYC Sass Meetup.

Du Hoang is going to teach you how to create arrows, talk bubbles, ribbons, and other effects in CSS, and animate them. Then use Sass to build a library of your favorite CSS effects. Huzzah!

Jeff Escalante returns to podium to show us about the power of @extend and how to use it to create elegant styleguides that keep your files DRY. Extend is a killer Sass feature. If you don't know it, your in for a great holiday gift.

And if you have any code, pet projects, questions, suggestions, we'll be opening up the floor for 15 minutes at the end for anyone to speak or share their sassy thoughts.

Speakers

Du Hoang is the Interactive Art Director at CalorieCount.com. He specializes in both design and frontend dev, and thinks that magic happens when code and design collide. You can follow him on Twitter @duhoang.

Jeff Escalante is a hybrid developer who slings code at Carrot Creative in Brooklyn. He has a extensive background in both design and programming, which makes him really excited about the intersection between the two - front-end development. He would love to talk with you about css, coffeescript, fluffy animals, and/or ruby. Outside of work Jeff has been widely recognized for his expertise in trolling

Sponsors

Fabulous refreshments and space are kindly sponsored by Pivotal Labs NYC. Thank you @pivotalnyc for supporting emerging technologies and letting us build the NYC Sass community.

Super big thanks to Vox Media. Vox has been supporting NYC Sass since our inception. We couldn't have done it without you!
results.name: Snazzy CSS Effects with Sass & Using @extend to Build/Design Styleguides

June's Workshop: NYC Sass Meetup Website

We've outgrown Meetup.com and would like our own place on the web to call home (similar to what New York Tech Meetup did with NYTM.org)/ We'll come with wires, we need designers, coders, and sass enthusiasts to turn them around into our very own NYC Sass Site. We'll work through the process together. The goal is to learn and share our processes in getting from design to final code product.

You don't need to participate in the workshop to attend the hack day. If you have question, concerns, want some one-on-one, come on up to Simple Reach.

Show and Tell

What have you been working? What cool, a-ha moment have you had recently? Are you using a shiny, new modern front-end tool, did you write a new extension, are you head-over-heels for a framework? Bring code, tips, tricks, and your tid-bits to our first Sassy Show-n-Tell.

We will be co-hosting this event with the NY Responsive Web Design meetup
results.name: Markup to Mobile: HTML and Sass for Responsive Web Design

results.description:
And...we're back for the first Meetup since our hiatus for SassConf.

This month we'll hear from array of Sass enthusiasts about their partial and folder organizational structure. It's a nation-wide panel, as in we'll hear from both local and remote Sass aficionados.

We'll also spend some time talking about SassConf. For those that missed the fun and awesomeness that was SassConf, you'll get a chance to hear from some of the conference speakers at the Meetup.

Featured Presenters
Jackie Balzer Lead Front-End Developer at Behance

Tim Hettler Senior Open Standards Developer at R/GA

Dale Sande UI Developer at CodeFellows in Seattle

Eric Meyer Designer and Developer at Oddbird.

Mason Wendell Coding Designer at NBC Universal

...you?
results.name: This is how we do it; or, Partial/Folder Structure/Organization.

results.description:
New version of Sass dropped last year. Let's take a look at the newness. We'll also spend time on more advanced Sass features focusing on how you can start to use them in your work.

Since we couldn't have December Holiday party, we'll have dinner + sweets this month.

results.description:
New version of Sass dropped last year. Let's take a look at the newness. We'll also spend time on more advanced Sass features focusing on how you can start to use them in your work.

results.name: Rescheduled: It's the New Year! Dive into new and more advanced Sass features

results.description:
Case Study from Meetup.com (surprise, they use Sass, too!)

Front end code at Meetup suffers from the same kind of problems that many ongoing projects have, with the added complication of the codebase being close to 10 years old. Adam will be covering how Meetup uses the strangler vine pattern as a strategy for making the old new, their custom CSS foundation (Sassquatch), and some results from the last two years of cleanup effort.

Speaker


Adam Detrick is a UI engineer with a background focusing on the intersection of design, code, and performance. As a Design Architect at Meetup, he works with both the design and engineering teams, helping build the future of Meetup front end and giving projects silly names.
results.name: Sass at Meetup.com: Using custom CSS foundations to purge legacy code

results.description:
Details

Bermon Painter will go into a deep code dive and go over a case study of some recent work he's been doing for some enterprise level clients.
results.name: Bermon Painter on Pattern Libraries

results.description: LibSass. What is it, how do you use it and what is it's impact on the Sass community as a whole? Dale Sande has been using LibSass on projects that are not really open to the idea of a Ruby dependency. Dale will be sharing both interesting challenges that have arisen and new solutions.
results.name: All the cool kids are talking about LibSass

results.description:
Joining us from Chicago GothamSass gives a very special welcome to Shay Howe, Jon Buda and JC Grubbs. The trio are taking a five day road trip across the country spending time with the local community of designers and developers.

Their talks deal with constraints. With everything we build we face constraints. We’ll discuss these constraints and how we can best leverage them to our benefit

http://refreshroadtrip.com/.

JC Grubbs
Check & Balance
In any product construction effort there are many processes: ideation and product definition, design, user testing, software engineering, operations, etc. Healthy product ecosystems employ checks and balances to ensure that good communication and coordination are occurring. In this talk we’ll explore some of the ways these constraints can be applied throughout a team to increase overall effectiveness and happiness.

JC Grubbs is the CEO and Practice Lead at DevMynd, a software design and development studio in Chicago. JC has spent the last 15 years working in technology professional services and has lead teams from small to large. Over his career he has filled many roles from developer to architect to product owner.


Jon Buda,
Design Your Way Out of a Hole Using Constraints

A blank slate can be an intimidating and overwhelming place to be when designing a new project. Setting constraints and boundaries can help you focus in on the most important aspects of a project, gain important clarity, and allows you to make decisions quicker and easier. Learn a few tricks to setting up your own constraints and how using them can help you push past design roadblocks.


Jon Buda is web developer who loves to design, or a designer who loves to code – depending on the day. He enjoys solving problems holistically, thinking about back-end, front-end, and design all as equally important parts in crafting great experiences. He helps to organize Refresh Chicago.


Shay Howe
How Constraints Cultivate Growth

By setting constraints, we force ourselves to be more productive. They help us make decisions, creating focus around the problem we are trying to solve. They improve our consistency, which provides a better experience for our users. And they help us grow, a valuable asset in times of innovation. We’ll discuss constraints and ways we can embrace them.

As a designer and front end developer, Shay Howe specializes in product design and interface development, specialties in which he regularly writes and speaks about. Currently he is the Director of Product at Belly, and co-organizes Chicago Camps, Refresh Chicago, and UX Happy Hour.
results.name: On Constraints with Shay Howe, Jon Buda & JC Grubbs

results.description:
Now you too can beautiful, harmonious designs. Ian will cover how to use Sass, Ems and pixel based borders to set type with modular scale and maintain vertical rhythm for every element in your layout

Ian Rose is a UX Designer at NBC News Digital, he works with a team of editors, designers, and developers to help deliver the news to users.
results.name: Mastering Vertical Rhythm & Modular Scale with Ian Rose, UXD NBC News Digital

results.description:
Come Hack on Sass!

If you want to learn something in particular, post to comments. If you are working on a project and want input, bring it with you. Come with your computers and a mind willing to share and learn.
results.name: SassHack: Bring questions, your projects, your knowledge.

results.description:
Are you looking to take your Sass chops to the next level? Are you just starting out with Sass and want to cut straight through the cruft to best practices and techniques? This 2hr SassShop is a hands on experience designed to cover the Sass feature set from a practical, daily use perspective. Our goal is to have you leaving feeling more comfortable with Sass. We hope you will walk out with new Sassy insights to take back to your team or solo-practice as well as techniques for improving your front-end development process.

Requirements

Comfort and knowledge with CSS and HTML. If you are new to CSS, this workshop will be too advanced for you.

Due to limitations of time, please come with Sass running on your computer. If you need help setting up your development environment, please reach out to Claudina in advance.

RSVP:

Space is limited. Kindly RSVP if you are 110% certain you will attend. We will host another SassShop if there is community interest.

Instructor:

Claudina Sarahe is a front-end architect at OddBird. She's the co-founder of SassConf and GothamSass Meetup. Follow her @itsmisscs
results.name: SassShop: 2hr Sass Workshop (Beginner to Intermediate)

results.description:
N.B. This workshop will be very similar to last Thursday's workshop. If you attended on Thursday, kindly let other community members register first.

Are you looking to take your Sass chops to the next level? Are you just starting out with Sass and want to cut straight through the cruft to best practices and techniques? This 2hr SassShop is a hands on experience designed to cover the Sass feature set from a practical, daily use perspective. Our goal is to have you leaving feeling more comfortable with Sass. We hope you will walk out with new Sassy insights to take back to your team or solo-practice as well as techniques for improving your front-end development process.

Requirements

Comfort and knowledge with CSS and HTML. If you are new to CSS, this workshop will be too advanced for you.

Due to limitations of time, please come with Sass running on your computer. If you need help setting up your development environment, please reach out to Claudina in advance.

Highly Recommenced: If you are not using rbenv, a build tool, and/or bundler and want to know why these tools are fundamental to a better Sass workflow, watch Ian Carrico's excellent 2013 SassConf talk Taking the Pain Out of Sass in advance of class.

RSVP:


Space is limited. Kindly RSVP if you are 110% certain you will attend. We will continue to host more SassShops if there is community interest continues to be so overwhelming.

Instructor:


Claudina Sarahe is a front-end architect at OddBird. She's the co-founder of SassConf and GothamSass Meetup. Follow her @itsmisscs
results.name: SassShop: 2hr Sass Workshop (Beginner to Intermediate)

results.description:
So. Many. Grid. Frameworks. #mindexploding

This month we will hear from few speakers on their grid framework of choice. Lightening talk style.

NEAT

There is a trifecta of time-tested, whiskey-related Sass libraries in the preprocessor ecosystem, among them is “a lightweight, semantic grid framework” called Neat. This lightning talk will go over the pros & cons of using such a framework for creating slick, Sass-powered web projects, and how it works in conjunction with its sibling tools, Bourbon and Bitters.

Nick Hehr is a creator for and explore of the web & beyond. His latest title is Product Designer & Front-End Developer, but he is known to work in whatever medium best suits the project. He enjoys using tools backed by great communities and focuses on turning awesome ideas into the best user experiences. He also has a sweet mustache.

Singularity

A lightening talk from Sam Richard, lead maintainer.
results.name: Battle of the Grids pt. 1

results.description:
Do you have questions that want answered? If so, Schedule a question:
https://gothamsass.hackpad.com/SassHack-Template-JztAsPQ5miW

Do you want to offer help? Browse questions:
https://gothamsass.hackpad.com/ep/group/qPWUaSdCDSM

Feel free to shout any questions to me, either here or on twitter, @nonlinear
results.name: SassHack: Bring questions, your projects, your knowledge.

results.description:
Come kick of #SassConf14 with our first of 3 awesome weekly community events.

Tonight we'll hear from two of 2014 speakers on how they use Sass in their companies. Followed by ample time for Q&A.

Whether or not you planning on coming to SassConf this a special opportunity to meet and chat with exemplary leaders in front-end development and design

Speakers

Patrick Hamann

Patrick Hamann (@patrickhamann) is a Senior Software Engineer at The Guardian. Come hear about the process of building the next-generation of the Guardian.

Smith Schwartz


Smith Schwartz (@smithschwartz) is a former museum experience designer and digital nomad. She currently lives in San Francisco and is an Interaction Designer at Say Media, building the future of web-based publishing. Smith is in charge all the Sass, changing themes on multiple digital properties with one configuration partial. And she's doing it all with LibSass.


This #SassWeek event is sponsored by XO Tech.


Thank you XO Tech and XO Group for refreshments and space.

XO Tech is building innovative products that continue to revolutionize how women visualize, plan for and enjoy life's most important moments. We are highly focused on building a user-centric, product focused, mobile first organization with a refreshing, fun and entrepreneurial work culture. For everyone at XO Group, a collaborative spirit is a must. Our teams are very dedicated and excited about what they do — and we work hard to maintain that atmosphere.

#SassWeek is a partnership between SassConf and GothamSass, NYCs monthly Sass Meetup.
results.name: Talks & Q&A: Smith Schwartz, Say Media, & Patrick Hamann, The Guardian

results.description:
Come kick of #SassConf14 with our second weekly community event.


Tonight we'll hear from another one of of 2014 speakers, Adam Onishi, on nurturing the roots of front-end development. Followed by ample time for Q&A.

Whether or not you planning on coming to SassConf this a special treat to meet exemplary leaders in the front-end community and chat one-on-one with speakers from out of town.

</a>

<a>Adam Onishi (@onishiweb)

Adam is senior front end developer at London based digital agency <a>Architect</a>. He's worked on a variety of projects for all sorts of clients ranging from corporations like Unilever and even some celebrities like The Hoff and Sting! He once wrote a book on WordPress and has organised events and a Christmas themed community development blog under the banner of 12 Devs. Adam is a regular cyclist and fan of fantasy novels and comic books.

Sponsor

This event in the #SassWeek series is sponsored by ThoughtBot.

Core supporters of Bourbon, Neat, and many other open source projects. Also, we <3 SASS! We are a team of designers and developers. Clients hire us to solve problems for people. So, we interview potential customers. We sketch. We prototype. We make and ship working software, and we measure use of the software. Find us on Twitter @thoughtbot, or check out our blog at Giant Robots Smashing Into Other Giant Robots.

#SassWeek is a partnership between SassConf and GothamSass, NYCs monthly Sass Meetup.
results.how_to_find_us: Lobby 1st floor around the corner on Charlton st.
results.name: #SassWeek Q&A with SassConf 2014 speaker Adam Onishi

results.description:
Remember last year when Jina sent off this tweet heard round the world?


Come open the second year of SassConf with a fireside chat with Team Sass Design, a volunteer task force who redesigned the brand and website for Sass, when Chris Eppstein tweeted his frustration with there not being many designers volunteering in the open source community.

Team Sass Design was shortlisted for Best Collaborative Project from Net Awards.

Natalie Weizenbaum, Primary Developer and Architect of Sass

Chris Eppstein, Core Contributor to Sass & Senior Engineer at LinkedIn

Jina Bolton, Team Sass Design Lead & Senior Product Designer at Salesforce UX


Bermon Painter, Designer of the new Sass logo

Joining them and guiding the conversation will be Hampton Catlin, Creator of Sass and Camp Sass.


It's truly a rare moment when the trifecta of Sass—Natalie, Hampton, Chris —are all in one room—let alone every person that contributed to design and make the new face for the community! Last year at SassConf 2013 was the first time in a very long time that we were able to get them all together so we're lucky to have the opportunity to again. A fitting kick-off for SassConf 2014.


If you are registered for SassConf, you can check-in early for the conference. Come get your tote and tee. Please RSVP for this event via the Paperless Post invitation.

Tonight's opening night event is open to any interested member of GothamSass and their guests. You do not need to have a SassConf ticket to attend but RSVPs are limited for non-ticket holders.


Refreshments provided by Meetup.

Opening Night Fireside Chat is generously sponsored by Meetup.com.


Meetup's mission is to revitalize local community and help people around the world self-organize. Meetup believes that people can change their personal world, or the whole world, by organizing themselves into groups that are powerful enough to make a difference.


Learn more on the Meetup HQ Blog.

SassConf 2014 is underwritten Hoefler & Co and IBM Design.


SassConf sponsored by OddBird and MakerSquare. For a complete list of all our supporters and information about each of our wonderful sponsors visit http://sassconf.com/sponsors
results.name: Official SassConf Opening Reception: Fireside Chat with Team Sass Design

results.description:
The SassConf party boat is ready to set sail! Come get sassy on a cruise with your fellow Sasstronauts! Karaoke, food, and an open bar are all here! Sponsored by Hoefler & Co.

Tickets are extremely limited. If you already have a ticket from SassConf you do not need to purchase one here. Only ticketed guests will be admitted.
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the end of Pier 61, say you're there for the SassConf party, we will check you in.
results.name: SassConf Party Boat!

meta.title: Meetup Events v2
meta.description: Access Meetup events using a group, member, or event id. Events in private groups are available only to authenticated members of those groups. To search events by topic or location, see [Open Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/open_events).
